done
license service/feature design?
Ack
implement redfish license install/delete interfaces for redfish client?
Ack
lets talk about using pldm file IO commands
Ack

host send json file with all existing license details
license manager parses json file and populate d-bus object for each license.
lets add these details
Ack
will add impacted components ?
you mean Bmcweb, hmc and pldm?
Yes bmcweb, license-manager and pldm impact
I mean we can explain impact on these repo in few words
Ack
lets mention testing that needs to be done for these interfaces
add testing scenarios?
Ack
No alternatives?
Ack
I think D-bus call happens after creating task
Updated the diagram
There is no way this is ready for review.
do you have any specific comments?

1. There are large sections of the design template that have been deleted and not filled in. 

2. There have been multiple email discussions on this topic previously that should be referenced and the issues in those emails addressed.
Ack

Just so it isn't missed, this email is where I wrote up a lot of the issues with this feature from an open source project perspective. 
 I've not really seen any discussion in the recent past that would address my concerns.
 
https://lore.kernel.org/openbmc/YJLXlNyk%2Fc8IVf9e@heinlein/
Hi Patrick, thank you for pointing this out. I have reinitiated this email.
Have gone through the mail. The document has been updated with details of what exactly is the involvement of BMC in the licensing use case.
Use capital letters as Platform Level Data Model. Same below.
Ack
Its not 'extra'. By purchasing licenses.
Ack
One of the examples would be to control the firmware updates using licenses, by not allowing the new driver installation which is release beyond certain date which system is entitled for.
Ack
Who will take care of the license expiration? Will there be any alarms/events generated when the license expires? Please mention the scope and future enhancements possible on this license manager.
Ack

Hello Abhilash,

I've made some comments inline. However, I do ask that you review the guidelines for writing a design document. Particularly:

> - The focus of the document is to define the problem we need to solve and
>   analyse the trade-offs of different solutions. You should concentrate on
>   interactions between components, though analysing the trade-offs often
>   requires you to explore how each might be implemented.
>
> - Write this document as an [argumentative essay][argumentative-essay]. Good
>   design proposals compel the reviewers agree with the proposal's conclusions.
> 
> [argumentative-essay]: https://www.grammarly.com/blog/argumentative-essay/

You can find these guidelines at the top of the template:

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/717d273cf8bceac3868a278aeb34d19e8d74c1b3/designs/design-template.md#L3-L48

My feeling is this document is not enough of an argumentative essay to be compelling. Further, it needs to address the issues raised on the mailing list in the past as part of its discussion. Those concerns need to be invalidated by your argument.

Ack
I thought that since there is already a redfish schema available, the interface are agreed and finalized. 
Will gather the conversations and update the document accordingly.
I have to say these acronyms are unfortunate. I'd prefer we keep referring to PLDM as PLDM and refer to the license manager as "license manager" without abbreviation.
Removed. Used License Manager instead.

PLDM isn't just for talking to a host. Many devices in the system may be capable of PLDM exchanges. Please rework this sentence (and possibly your understanding of the purpose of PLDM, as opposed to just its use in e.g. Power platforms).
Added PLDM details applicable for the license use case
I don't think this is justified, yet.
If PLDM can host the Dbus objects then the License manager is not needed. I am open for that. PLDM member has to comment on it.

I don't think it's worth repeating this diagram just to indicate the change from the license manager process to the PLDM daemon. What is the *impact* of such a change? Why is it not something we should consider?
Removed the diagram
What does this mean? There are not enough words here.
Added details.

Are these automated or manual tests? If they are automated where will they be integrated? If they are manual, why? How do we address the maintenance burden of people not testing the infrastructure (because it's a manual process, and people just won't).
There is no plan automating these cases in CI. I will update the document once proper tools for automations are  identified
As per the community email - lets remove this usecase and reduce the scope
None
Done

There will be an impact in the host component, who will process the received licenses and validate and install them. This is out of BMC design, but still lets mention that in generic to highlight that there will be no validation and installation of licenses on the BMC, and for BMC resources/features.
Done
Please add test cases, and mention what all among them can be automated.
Done
Hi Abilash, a couple of things still need clarification in my opinion. I've left comments inline.

What do you mean by 7? The way it's described makes it sound like you plan on using inotify? If so, that's not a direction I would prefer this to take. This can all be achieved through DBus without invoking inotify.

I think it would be best to have a discussion of the concrete DBus interfaces and objects exposed by the services to help clarify the intent.

Given that bmcweb is handling the redfish request, the download manager is handling the file transfer, the host is handling licence validation, and pldmd is hosting license-related data provided by the host, the role of the license manager is not entirely clear to me.

What are the significant negative impacts on pldmd that make it a poor choice?

+1

If the license manager is just for grabbing the licenses , why can't pldm do it ? why do we need a separate application ?

Are we also thinking about a design on systems that does not have a working pldm stack ? are we also planning to for example : have ipmi work as well to transfer the data ?
Let me go through the PLDM design first. I can get back on the pros and cons after that.
Moving the logic of hosting license data at pldm makes sense. This removes the need of maintaining the new repo and supporting a new application at BMC.

We had some discussion about the scope of PLDM and some history of objections in hosting new Dbus objects in PLDM. Now there is an alignment on not to go for new service just for hosting some Dbus objects. I will update the design document with the removal of license manager from it.
i believe this is just host firmware/hypervisor/BIOS firmware ? that can talk PLDM ? not a separate machine ?
Ack

we are talking a fair bit of pldm in this document without any PLDM spec level details, it would be good to include details about what pldm commands would come into play for this license transfers & is that a generic spec or an oem customization ? 

Having those details in here would help get a better picture.
